p:
Sea-surface temperature (in Celsius), T( t), was obtained by curve fitting satellite data (see below), using the following equation:
2
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$T(t)={I}_{ave}({a}_{1}\,\cos (t)+{a}_{2}\,\sin (t))+\lambda t+{a}_{3},$$\end{document}

,
where I
ave is the annual average of irradiance (in photosynthetic available radiation, PAR), and the parameters a 1 and a 2 are the rates at which irradiance affects the change in temperature (or the rate of change in Celsius per PAR) (in Celsius/PAR). We assume that seasonal irradiance does not vary among years. Here, λ is defined as the ‘climate-change coefficient’ (Celsius time −1), where λt controls the temperature increase over time, in years, and a 3 is the annual average of sea surface temperature (in Celsius) for λ = 0 under normal, non-anomalous years (Table 1). To estimate these parameters we used nonlinear optimization using the program Mathematica®.
